title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement phgrosjean@sciviews.org. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Statistical Models for 'SciViews::R'
text: Load required packages example. Loblolly dataset used illustrate {modelit} features. focuses growth Loblolly pine trees (Pinus tadea L. 1753). dataset three variables: height, age, seed. Heigth  [m] Age  [years] Seed 1.37 3 301 3.32 5 301 8.75 10 301 12.72 15 301 16.06 20 301 ... ... ... 2.76 5 331 7.88 10 331 11.93 15 331 14.97 20 331 18.13 25 331 First last 5 rows total 84 plot data chart(), automatically using labels units defined :  keep one measurement per tree (alias Seed) get dataset independent observations adjust simple linear model.  fit quadratic model data. Compare “raw” summary lm object version formatted using tabularise(). Linear model NA Term Estimate Standard Error t value p value  \alpha -2.0393 0.2895 -7.04 2.14·10-05 *** \beta_{1} 1.1344 0.0584 19.41 7.37·10-10 *** \beta_{2} -0.0127 0.0021 -6.06 8.14·10-05 *** 0 <= '***' < 0.001 < '**' < 0.01 < '*' < 0.05 Residuals range: [-0.5508, 0.6427] Residuals standard error: 0.3345 11 degrees freedom Multiple R2: 0.9981   -   adjusted R2: 0.9978 F-statistic: 2951 2 11 df   -   p value: 9.6175e-16 equation can directly displayed R Markdown Quarto document equation(pine_lm) code inline R chunk. \[ \operatorname{Heigth \ [m]} = \alpha + \beta_{1}(\operatorname{Age \ [years]}) + \beta_{2}(\operatorname{age^{2}}) + \epsilon \] Several plots also available chart(), starting graph showing model fitted data:  plots analysis residuals chart() variants can indicated short form chart$<type>() function possible types : "resfitted", "qqplot", "scalelocation", "cooksd", "resleverage", "cookleverage", "reshist", "resautocor". composite plot, incorporating four used residual analysis charts, obtained "residuals" type (note four charts labeled -D facilitate description legend).
code: library(modelit) library(tabularise) library(chart) library(dplyr) data("Loblolly", package = "datasets") # convert feet to meters Loblolly$height <- round(Loblolly$height * 0.3048, 2) # Add labels and units Loblolly <- data.io::labelise(Loblolly,   label = list(height = "Heigth", age = "Age", Seed = "Seed"),   units = list(height = "m", age = "years"))  # First and last rows of the dataset with tabularise tabularise$headtail(Loblolly) #> Warning in set2(resolve(...)): The object is read-only and cannot be modified. #> If you have to modify it for a legitimate reason, call the method $lock(FALSE) #> on the object before $set(). Using $lock(FALSE) to modify the object will be #> enforced in future versions of knitr and this warning will become an error. chart(Loblolly, height ~ age %col=% Seed) +   geom_line() set.seed(3652) pine <- dplyr::slice_sample(Loblolly, n = 1, by = Seed) chart(pine, height ~ age) +    geom_point() pine_lm <- lm(data = pine, height ~ age + I(age^2)) summary(pine_lm) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = height ~ age + I(age^2), data = pine) #>  #> Residuals: #>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max  #> -0.55076 -0.13703  0.08873  0.13593  0.64271  #>  #> Coefficients: #>              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept) -2.039295   0.289531  -7.043 2.14e-05 *** #> age          1.134437   0.058449  19.409 7.37e-10 *** #> I(age^2)    -0.012705   0.002095  -6.064 8.14e-05 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 0.3345 on 11 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.9981, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9978  #> F-statistic:  2951 on 2 and 11 DF,  p-value: 9.617e-16 summary(pine_lm) |>    tabularise()  #> Warning in set2(resolve(...)): The object is read-only and cannot be modified. #> If you have to modify it for a legitimate reason, call the method $lock(FALSE) #> on the object before $set(). Using $lock(FALSE) to modify the object will be #> enforced in future versions of knitr and this warning will become an error. chart(pine_lm) # Equivalent to : chart$model(pine_lm) chart$residuals(pine_lm)

title: Statistical Models for 'SciViews::R'
text: objects also supported {modelit}. instance, nonlinear model can fitted dataset. Gompertz model suitable growth measurements. Nonlinear least squares  Gompertz model NA Term Estimate Standard Error tobs. value p value  20.765 0.72637 28.6 1.13·10-11 *** b1 3.755 0.20549 18.3 1.40·10-09 *** b2 0.876 0.00827 105.9 < 2·10-16 *** 0 <= '***' < 0.001 < '**' < 0.01 < '*' < 0.05 Residual standard error : 0.4076 11 degrees freedom Number iterations convergence : 4 Achieved convergence tolerance : 5.673e-06 plot model superposed data can obtained chart().
code: pine_nls <- nls(data = pine, height ~ SSgompertz(age, a, b1, b2)) summary(pine_nls) |>    tabularise() #> Warning in set2(resolve(...)): The object is read-only and cannot be modified. #> If you have to modify it for a legitimate reason, call the method $lock(FALSE) #> on the object before $set(). Using $lock(FALSE) to modify the object will be #> enforced in future versions of knitr and this warning will become an error. chart(pine_nls, lang = "fr")

title: Statistical Models for SciViews::R
text: {modelit} available CRAN yet. install SciViews R-Universe. {chart} alternate formula interface {ggplot2}. {tabularise} produces publication-ready (rich-formatted) tabular output. {equatags} {equatiomatic} packages optional, useful display equations, inline R Markdown/Quarto documents {tabularise} tables. {data.io} useful manages labels units {chart} uses. install six packages dependencies, run following command R: can also install latest development version {modelit}. Make sure {remotes} R package installed:
code: install.packages(c('modelit', 'chart', 'tabularise', 'equatags', 'equatiomatic', 'data.io'),   repos = c('https://sciviews.r-universe.dev', 'https://cloud.r-project.org')) # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("SciViews/modelit")

title: Statistical Models for SciViews::R
text: trees datasets present diameter, height volume Black Cherry Trees (Prunus serotina, Ehrh., 1788) perform polynomial regression volume timber function girth trees. model can viewed using chart():  Residual analysis plots can also carried chart().  examples, please, refer help pages https://www.sciviews.org/modelit/.
code: library(modelit) library(tabularise) library(chart) data('trees', package = 'datasets') trees_lm <- lm(Volume ~ Girth + I(Girth^2), data = trees) summary(trees_lm) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = Volume ~ Girth + I(Girth^2), data = trees) #>  #> Residuals: #>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max  #> -5.4889 -2.4293 -0.3718  2.0764  7.6447  #>  #> Coefficients: #>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept) 10.78627   11.22282   0.961 0.344728     #> Girth       -2.09214    1.64734  -1.270 0.214534     #> I(Girth^2)   0.25454    0.05817   4.376 0.000152 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 3.335 on 28 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.9616, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9588  #> F-statistic: 350.5 on 2 and 28 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16 chart(trees_lm) chart$residuals(trees_lm)

title: Transform an lm or glm model into a function — as.function.lm
code: data("trees", package = "datasets") trees_lm1 <- lm(Volume ~ Girth, data = trees) trees_lm2 <- lm(Volume ~ Girth + I(Girth^2), data = trees)  # Compare these two models on a chart library(chart) #> Loading required package: ggplot2 #> Loading required package: lattice chart(trees, Volume ~ Girth) +   geom_point() +   stat_function(fun = as.function(trees_lm1), col = "red") +   stat_function(fun = as.function(trees_lm2), col = "blue")   # The created function can also be used for easy predictions trees_fn1 <- as.function(trees_lm1) trees_fn1(10:20) # Volume for Girth 10:20 #>        1        2        3        4        5        6        7        8  #> 13.71511 18.78096 23.84682 28.91267 33.97853 39.04439 44.11024 49.17610  #>        9       10       11  #> 54.24196 59.30781 64.37367

title: Transform an nls model into a function — as.function.nls
code: data("ChickWeight", package = "datasets") chick1 <- ChickWeight[ChickWeight$Chick == 1, ]  # Adjust a logistic curve chick1_logis <- nls(weight ~ SSlogis(Time, Asym, xmid, scal), data = chick1)  # Show this on a ggplot library(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(chick1, aes(x = Time, y = weight)) +   geom_point() +   stat_function(fun = as.function(chick1_logis), col = "red") p   # Visually compare with another model (four-parameter logistic): chick1_fpl <- nls(weight ~ SSfpl(Time, A, B, xmid, scal), data = chick1)  p + stat_function(fun = as.function(chick1_fpl), col = "blue")

what: Chart an lm or glm model or diagnose its residuals visually — chart.lm
title: Chart an lm or glm model or diagnose its residuals visually — chart.lm
text: methods autoplot() chart() lm glm objects. type = model (default chart()), scatterplot model superimposed produced, providing model two numeric variables (combination ). types allow analyze residuals model.

title: Chart an lm or glm model or diagnose its residuals visually — chart.lm
code: # S3 method for lm chart(   data,   type = "model",   ...,   origdata = NULL,   title,   labels = "AUTO",   name = deparse(substitute(data)),   lang = getOption("data.io_lang", "en"),   env = parent.frame() )  autoplot.lm(   object,   origdata = NULL,   type = c("model", "resfitted", "qqplot", "scalelocation", "cooksd", "resleverage",     "cookleverage", "reshist", "resautocor"),   title,   xlab,   ylab,   ...,   name = deparse(substitute(object)),   lang = getOption("data.io_lang", "en"),   env = parent.frame() )

title: Chart an lm or glm model or diagnose its residuals visually — chart.lm
text: data lm glm model. type type plot: "model", "resfitted", "qqplot", "scalelocation", "cooksd", "resleverage", "cookleverage", "reshist" "resautocor". chart(), can also provided chart$type(....).  chart() also uses "residuals" constructs combined figure resfitted, qqplot, scalelocation resleverage. ... Additional arguments passed chart.`` origdata original dataset model fitted . required type = model case untransformed X variable model. title title plot. provided, default title computed. labels vector four character strings, one plot done chart$residuals(). name name model. provided, name model object default. lang language use titles labels, currently "en" "fr".` env environment evaluate code. parent.frame() default, reasons change , unless really know ! object Idem xlab label X axis. default label proposed provided. ylab label Y axis (default provided).

title: Chart an lm or glm model or diagnose its residuals visually — chart.lm
text: ggplot object produced.

title: Chart an lm or glm model or diagnose its residuals visually — chart.lm
code: library(chart) data(trees, package = "datasets") trees_lm <- lm(Volume ~ Girth, data = trees) chart(trees_lm) # origdata not needed because untransformed variables  # Residuals analysis chart$resfitted(trees_lm)  chart$qqplot(trees_lm)  chart$scalelocation(trees_lm)  chart$cooksd(trees_lm)  chart$resleverage(trees_lm)  chart$cookleverage(trees_lm)  chart$reshist(trees_lm, bins = 15)  chart$resautocor(trees_lm)   # The four most important residual analysis plots in one figure chart$residuals(trees_lm)   trees_lm2 <-  lm(Volume ~ log(Girth), data = trees) chart(trees_lm2, origdata = trees) # origdata needed, cf. transformed Girth  trees_lm3 <- lm(Volume ~ Girth + Height, data = trees) # chart(trees_lm3) # Error because more than 2 variables! # Polynomial regressions work too trees_lm4 <- lm(Volume ~ I(Girth^2) + Girth, data = trees) chart(trees_lm4)  # or using poly() trees_lm5 <- lm(Volume ~ poly(Girth, 3), data = trees) chart(trees_lm5, origdata = trees) # origdata required here!

text: Create model equation several self-starting nonlinear models available stats package.

title: Get a LaTeX equation from an nls or the summary of a nls models — equation.nls
code: # S3 method for nls equation(   object,   ital_vars = FALSE,   use_coefs = FALSE,   coef_digits = 2L,   fix_signs = TRUE,   var_names = NULL,   op_latex = c("\\cdot", "\\times"),   ... )  # S3 method for summary.nls equation(   object,   ital_vars = FALSE,   use_coefs = FALSE,   coef_digits = 2L,   fix_signs = TRUE,   var_names = NULL,   op_latex = c("\\cdot", "\\times"),   ... )

title: Get a LaTeX equation from an nls or the summary of a nls models — equation.nls
text: object nls summary.nls object. ital_vars Logical, defaults FALSE. variable names wrapped \operatorname command? use_coefs Logical, defaults FALSE. actual model estimates included equation instead math symbols? TRUE, var_names= ignored. coef_digits Integer, defaults 2. number decimal places round displaying model estimates use_coefs = TRUE. fix_signs Logical, defaults TRUE. disabled, coefficient estimates negative preceded + (e.g. 5(x) + -3(z)). enabled, + - replaced - (e.g. 5(x) - 3(z)). var_names named character vector c(old_var_name = "new name") op_latex LaTeX product operator character use fancy scientific notation, either \\cdot (default), \\times. ... Additional arguments (used yet).

title: Get a LaTeX equation from an nls or the summary of a nls models — equation.nls
text: character string LaTeX equation.

title: Get a LaTeX equation from an nls or the summary of a nls models — equation.nls
code: equation <- tabularise::equation chick1 <- ChickWeight[ChickWeight$Chick == 1, ] chick1_nls <- nls(data = chick1, weight ~ SSlogis(Time, Asym, xmid, scal)) summary(chick1_nls) #>  #> Formula: weight ~ SSlogis(Time, Asym, xmid, scal) #>  #> Parameters: #>      Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> Asym 937.0300   465.8677   2.011  0.07516 .   #> xmid  35.2230     8.3120   4.238  0.00218 **  #> scal  11.4052     0.9052  12.599 5.08e-07 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 2.919 on 9 degrees of freedom #>  #> Number of iterations to convergence: 0  #> Achieved convergence tolerance: 7.343e-06 #>   equation(chick1_nls) #> $$ #> \begin{aligned} \operatorname{weight} = \frac{Asym}{1 + e^{(xmid - \operatorname{Time}) /scal}} + \epsilon \end{aligned} #> $$ equation(summary(chick1_nls)) #> $$ #> \begin{aligned} \operatorname{weight} = \frac{Asym}{1 + e^{(xmid - \operatorname{Time}) /scal}} + \epsilon \end{aligned} #> $$  chick1_nls2 <- nls(data = chick1,   weight ~ SSlogis(Time, Asym = A, xmid = x, scal = scale)) summary(chick1_nls2) #>  #> Formula: weight ~ SSlogis(Time, Asym = A, xmid = x, scal = scale) #>  #> Parameters: #>       Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> A     937.0300   465.8677   2.011  0.07516 .   #> x      35.2230     8.3120   4.238  0.00218 **  #> scale  11.4052     0.9052  12.599 5.08e-07 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 2.919 on 9 degrees of freedom #>  #> Number of iterations to convergence: 0  #> Achieved convergence tolerance: 7.343e-06 #>   equation(chick1_nls2) #> $$ #> \begin{aligned} \operatorname{weight} = \frac{A}{1 + e^{(x - \operatorname{Time}) /scale}} + \epsilon \end{aligned} #> $$ equation(summary(chick1_nls2)) #> $$ #> \begin{aligned} \operatorname{weight} = \frac{A}{1 + e^{(x - \operatorname{Time}) /scale}} + \epsilon \end{aligned} #> $$  equation(summary(chick1_nls2), var_names = c(   weight = "Body weight [gm]",   Time = "Number of days")) #> $$ #> \begin{aligned} \operatorname{Body weight [gm]} = \frac{A}{1 + e^{(x - \operatorname{Number of days}) /scale}} + \epsilon \end{aligned} #> $$

text: model_fit object.

title: Fit a parsnip model and manipulate it as a base R model like lm — fit_model
code: library(parsnip) data(trees, package = "datasets")  # Take the habit to prefix your regression model specs by `reg_` reg_lm <- linear_reg(mod = "regression", engine = "lm") trees_fit <- fit_model$reg_lm(data = trees, Volume ~ Girth) #> Error in x(type = name, ...): The type= argument must provide a model_spec object or its name in a character string.  # You can use summary(), AIC(), anova(), tidy(), glance(), etc. directly summary(trees_fit) #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'trees_fit' not found anova(trees_fit) #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'trees_fit' not found AIC(trees_fit) #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'trees_fit' not found coef(trees_fit) #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'trees_fit' not found library(chart) chart(trees_fit) #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'trees_fit' not found # etc.

title: Statistical Models for 'SciViews::R' — modelit-package
text: {modelit} package provides extension base R functions model fitting like lm(), glm() nls() enhanced plots utilitarian functions.

title: Statistical Models for 'SciViews::R' — modelit-package
text: fit_model() creates model_fit object many methods. tabularise() methods lm, glm, nls, model_fit, anova aov objects. chart() methods lm, glm, nls model_fit objects. .function() transforms lm nls model function can plotted using stat_function().

title: Reexport of modelr functions — modelr-reexport
text: add_predictions() add_residuals() pipe-friendly functions add predictions residuals data frame. geom_ref_line() adds vertical horizontal reference line. rmse() (root-mean-squared-error), [mae[]] (mean absolute error), qae() (quantiles absolute error) rsquare() (variance predictions divided variance response) useful model metrics.

title: Reexport of modelr functions — modelr-reexport
code: add_predictions(data, model, var = "pred", type = NULL)  add_residuals(data, model, var = "resid")  geom_ref_line(h, v, color = "red", colour = color, size = 1)  rmse(model, data)  mae(model, data)  qae(model, data, probs = c(0.05, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.95))  rsquare(model, data)

title: Reexport of modelr functions — modelr-reexport
text: data data frame model model predict() method. var string name predictions residuals variable (default, "pred" "resid" respectively) type model's predict() method type= argument, can give . h Position horizontal reference line v Position vertical reference line color color reference line colour (use one prefer) size width reference line probs numeric vector probabilities

title: Reexport of modelr functions — modelr-reexport
text: function argument x returns values predicted model values x.

title: Reexport of modelr functions — modelr-reexport

title: Create a rich-formatted table using the coefficients of a glm object — tabularise_coef.glm
text: Extract format table coefficients glm object, similar stats::coef(), rich-formatted flextable object.

title: Create a rich-formatted table using the coefficients of a glm object — tabularise_coef.glm
code: # S3 method for glm tabularise_coef(   data,   header = TRUE,   title = NULL,   equation = header,   auto.labs = TRUE,   origdata = NULL,   labs = NULL,   lang = getOption("data.io_lang", "en"),   ...,   kind = "ft",   env = parent.frame() )

title: Create a rich-formatted table using the coefficients of a glm object — tabularise_coef.glm
text: data glm object header TRUE (default), add header table title TRUE, add title table header. Default value header, except outside chunk FALSE table caption detected (tbl-cap YAML entry). equation TRUE (default), add equation table header. equation can also passed form character string (LaTeX). auto.labs TRUE (default), use labels (units) automatically origdata=. origdata original data set model fitted . default NULL labels original data set used. labs Labels change names elements term column table. default, NULL change performed. lang natural language use. default value can set , e.g., options(data.io_lang = "fr") French. ... Additional arguments (used yet). kind kind table produce: "tt" tinytable, "ft" flextable (default). env environment evaluate lazyeval expressions (unused now).

title: Create a rich-formatted table using the coefficients of a glm object — tabularise_coef.glm
text: flextable object returned. can print different formats (HTML, LaTeX, Word, PowerPoint) rearrange {flextable} functions.

title: Create a rich-formatted table using the coefficients of an lm object — tabularise_coef.lm
text: data lm object header TRUE (default), add header table title TRUE, add title table header. Default value header, except outside chunk FALSE table caption detected (tbl-cap YAML entry). equation TRUE (default), add equation table header. equation can also passed form character string. auto.labs TRUE (default), use labels (units) automatically data origdata=. origdata original data set model fitted . default NULL label used. labs Labels change names elements term column table. default NULL nothing changed. lang natural language use. default value can set , e.g., options(data.io_lang = "fr") French. ... Additional arguments kind kind table produce: "tt" tinytable, "ft" flextable (default). env environment evaluate lazyeval expressions (unused now).

title: Create a rich-formatted table using the table of coefficients of the summary.nls object — tabularise_coef.summary.nls
text: function extracts formats table coefficients summary.nls object, similar stats::coef(), flextable object.

title: Create a rich-formatted table using the table of coefficients of the summary.nls object — tabularise_coef.summary.nls
code: # S3 method for summary.nls tabularise_coef(   data,   header = TRUE,   title = NULL,   equation = header,   lang = getOption("data.io_lang", "en"),   show.signif.stars = getOption("show.signif.stars", TRUE),   ...,   kind = "ft",   env = parent.frame() )

title: Create a rich-formatted table using the table of coefficients of the summary.nls object — tabularise_coef.summary.nls
text: data summary.nls object. header TRUE (default), add title table. title TRUE, add title table header. Default value header, except outside chunk FALSE table caption detected (tbl-cap YAML entry). equation Add equation model table. TRUE, equation() used. equation can also passed form character string (LaTeX equation). lang language use. default value can set , e.g., options(data.io_lang = "fr") French. show.signif.stars TRUE (default), add significance stars table. ... Additional arguments passed equation() kind kind table produce: "tt" tinytable, "ft" flextable (default). env environment evaluate lazyeval expressions (unused now).

title: Create a rich-formatted table using the table of coefficients of the summary.nls object — tabularise_coef.summary.nls
text: flextable object can print different forms rearrange {flextable} functions.

text: data anova object header TRUE (default), add header table title TRUE, add title table header. Default value header, except outside chunk FALSE table caption detected (tbl-cap YAML entry). auto.labs TRUE (default), use labels (units) automatically (origdata=) origdata original data set used ANOVA. default NULL. Used extract labels lost anova object. labs Labels change default names term column table. default NULL nothing changed. lang natural language use. default value set , e.g., options(data.io_lang = "fr") French. show.signif.stars TRUE, add significance stars table. default taken getOption("show.signif.stars"). ... Additional arguments (used now) kind kind table produce: "tt" tinytable, "ft" flextable (default). env environment evaluate lazyeval expressions (used now)

code: # S3 method for nls tabularise_default(   data,   header = TRUE,   title = NULL,   equation = header,   footer = TRUE,   lang = getOption("data.io_lang", "en"),   ...,   kind = "ft",   env = parent.frame() )

title: Create a rich-formatted table from a nls object — tabularise_default.nls
text: data nls object. header TRUE (default), add title table. title TRUE, add title table header. Default value header, except outside chunk FALSE table caption detected (tbl-cap YAML entry). equation Add equation model table. TRUE, equation() used. equation can also passed form character string (LaTeX equation). footer TRUE (default), add footer table. lang language use. default value can set , e.g., options(data.io_lang = "fr") French. ... Additional arguments. used. kind kind table produce: "tt" tinytable, "ft" flextable (default). env environment evaluate lazyeval expressions (unused now).

what: Create a rich-formatted table from the summary of a nls object — tabularise_default.summary.nls
title: Create a rich-formatted table from the summary of a nls object — tabularise_default.summary.nls
text: Create table summary.nls object. table looks like output print.summary.nls() richly formatted. tabularise_coef() function offers customization options object.

title: Create a rich-formatted table from the summary of a nls object — tabularise_default.summary.nls
code: # S3 method for summary.nls tabularise_default(   data,   header = TRUE,   title = NULL,   equation = header,   footer = TRUE,   lang = getOption("data.io_lang", "en"),   show.signif.stars = getOption("show.signif.stars", TRUE),   ...,   kind = "ft",   env = parent.frame() )

title: Create a rich-formatted table from the summary of a nls object — tabularise_default.summary.nls
text: data summary.nls object. header TRUE (default), add header table title TRUE, add title table header. Default value header, except outside chunk FALSE table caption detected (tbl-cap YAML entry). equation Add equation model table. TRUE, equation() used. equation can also passed form character string (LaTeX equation). footer TRUE (default), add footer table. lang language use. default value can set , e.g. options(data.io_lang = "fr") French. show.signif.stars TRUE (default), add significance stars table. ... Additional arguments (used). kind kind table produce: "tt" tinytable, "ft" flextable (default). env environment evaluate lazyeval expressions (unused now).

title: Create a rich-formatted table from the summary of a nls object — tabularise_default.summary.nls
text: flextable object can print different forms rearrange {flextable} functions.

Default value header, except outside chunk FALSE table caption detected (tbl-cap YAML entry). equation TRUE (default), add equation table header. equation can also passed form character string (LaTeX). auto.labs TRUE (default), use labels (units) automatically origdata=. origdata original data set model fitted . default NULL original labels used. labs Labels change names elements term column table. default NULL nothing changed. lang natural language use. default value can set , e.g., options(data.io_lang = "fr") French. ... Additional arguments passed tabularise::equation() kind kind table produce: "tt" tinytable, "ft" flextable (default). env environment evaluate lazyeval expressions (unused now).

title: Create a glance version of the glm object as a rich-formatted table — tabularise_glance.glm
text: flextable object produced can print different formats (HTML, LaTeX, Word, PowerPoint) rearrange {flextable} functions.

title: Glance version of the lm object into a flextable object — tabularise_glance.lm
code: # S3 method for lm tabularise_glance(   data,   header = TRUE,   title = NULL,   equation = TRUE,   auto.labs = TRUE,   origdata = NULL,   labs = NULL,   lang = getOption("data.io_lang", "en"),   ...,   kind = "ft",   env = parent.frame() )

title: Glance version of the lm object into a flextable object — tabularise_glance.lm
text: data lm object header TRUE (default), add header table title TRUE, add title table header. Default value header, except outside chunk FALSE table caption detected (tbl-cap YAML entry). equation TRUE (default), add equation table header. equation can also passed form character string (LaTeX). auto.labs TRUE (default), use labels (units) automatically data origdata=. origdata original data set model fitted . default NULL label used (name variables). labs Labels change names elements term column table. default NULL nothing changed. lang natural language use. default value can set , e.g., options(data.io_lang = "fr") French. ... Additional arguments passed tabularise::equation() kind kind table produce: "tt" tinytable, "ft" flextable (default). env environment evaluate lazyeval expressions (unused now).

title: Glance version of the nls object into a flextable object — tabularise_glance.nls
text: Extract information contained nls object table obtained broom::glance(). , table nicely formatted (almost) publication-ready form (good informal reports, notebooks, etc).

title: Glance version of the nls object into a flextable object — tabularise_glance.nls
code: # S3 method for nls tabularise_glance(   data,   header = TRUE,   title = NULL,   equation = header,   lang = getOption("data.io_lang", "en"),   ...,   kind = "ft",   env = parent.frame() )

title: Glance version of the nls object into a flextable object — tabularise_glance.nls
text: data nls object. header TRUE (default), add title table. title TRUE, add title table header. Default value header, except outside chunk FALSE table caption detected (tbl-cap YAML entry). equation Add equation model table. TRUE, equation() used. equation can also passed form character string (LaTeX). lang language use. default value can set , e.g., options(data.io_lang = "fr") French. ... Additional arguments passed equation() kind kind table produce: "tt" tinytable, "ft" flextable (default). env environment evaluate lazyeval expressions (unused now).

text: data anova object header TRUE (default), add header table title TRUE, add title table header. Default value header, except outside chunk FALSE table caption detected (tbl-cap YAML entry). auto.labs TRUE (default), use labels (units) origdata=. origdata original data set used ANOVA (used changing labels). default, NULL. labs Labels use change names elements term column. default, NULL. lang natural language use. default value can set , e.g., options(data.io_lang = "fr") French. show.signif.stars TRUE, add significance stars table. default taken getOption("show.signif.stars"). ... Additional arguments (used now) kind kind table produce: "tt" tinytable, "ft" flextable (default). env environment evaluate lazyeval expressions (used now)

what: Create a tidy version of the glm object as a rich-formatted table — tabularise_tidy.glm
title: Create a tidy version of the glm object as a rich-formatted table — tabularise_tidy.glm
text: Turn tidy glm object rich-formatted table {flextable}. table can printed different formats (HTML, LaTeX, Word, PowerPoint), rearranged later .

title: Create a tidy version of the glm object as a rich-formatted table — tabularise_tidy.glm
code: # S3 method for glm tabularise_tidy(   data,   header = TRUE,   title = NULL,   equation = header,   auto.labs = TRUE,   origdata = NULL,   labs = NULL,   conf.int = FALSE,   conf.level = 0.95,   lang = getOption("data.io_lang", "en"),   show.signif.stars = getOption("show.signif.stars", TRUE),   ...,   kind = "ft",   env = parent.frame() )

title: Create a tidy version of the glm object as a rich-formatted table — tabularise_tidy.glm
text: data glm object header TRUE (default), add header table title TRUE, add title table header. Default value header, except outside chunk FALSE table caption detected (tbl-cap YAML entry). equation TRUE (default), add equation table header. equation can also passed form character string (LaTeX). auto.labs TRUE (default), use labels (units) automatically origdata=. ` origdata original data set model fitted . default NULL variables labels data set used. labs Labels change names elements term column table. default NULL nothing changed. conf.int TRUE, add confidence interval. default FALSE. conf.level confidence level use confidence interval conf.int = TRUE. default 0.95. lang natural language use. default value can set , e.g., options(data.io_lang = "fr") French. show.signif.stars TRUE, add significance stars table. value obtained getOption("show.signif.stars"). ... Additional arguments passed tabularise::equation() kind kind table produce: "tt" tinytable, "ft" flextable (default). env environment evaluate lazyeval expressions (unused now).

title: Create a tidy version of the glm object as a rich-formatted table — tabularise_tidy.glm
text: flextable object returned. can print different formats (HTML, LaTeX, Word, PowerPoint), rearrange {flextable} functions.

what: Tidy version of the lm object into a flextable object — tabularise_tidy.lm
title: Tidy version of the lm object into a flextable object — tabularise_tidy.lm
text: Create rich-formatted table 'tidy' information lm object.

title: Tidy version of the lm object into a flextable object — tabularise_tidy.lm
code: # S3 method for lm tabularise_tidy(   data,   header = TRUE,   title = NULL,   equation = header,   auto.labs = TRUE,   origdata = NULL,   labs = NULL,   conf.int = FALSE,   conf.level = 0.95,   lang = getOption("data.io_lang", "en"),   show.signif.stars = getOption("show.signif.stars", TRUE),   ...,   kind = "ft",   env = parent.frame() )

title: Tidy version of the lm object into a flextable object — tabularise_tidy.lm
text: data lm object header TRUE (default), add header table title TRUE, add title table header. Default value header, except outside chunk FALSE table caption detected (tbl-cap YAML entry). equation TRUE (default), add equation table header. equation can also passed form character string (LaTeX). auto.labs TRUE (default), use labels (units) automatically data origdata=. origdata original data set model fitted . default NULL label used. labs Labels change names elements term column table. default NULL term changed. conf.int TRUE, add confidence interval. default FALSE. conf.level confidence level use confidence interval conf.int = TRUE. default 0.95. lang natural language use. default value can set , e.g., options(data.io_lang = "fr") French. show.signif.stars TRUE, add significance stars table. default getOption("show.signif.stars") ... Additional arguments passed tabularise::equation() kind kind table produce: "tt" tinytable, "ft" flextable (default). env environment evaluate lazyeval expressions (unused now).

title: Tidy version of the lm object into a flextable object — tabularise_tidy.lm
text: flextable object can print different formats (HTML, LaTeX, Word, PowerPoint) rearrange {flextable} functions.

title: Tidy version of the lm object into a flextable object — tabularise_tidy.lm

title: modelit 1.4.4
text: Argument kind = added tabularise() methods dependency update v0.6.0 {tabularise}. Enhanced vignette README file. License switched MIT.

title: modelit 1.4.3
text: Lack ... argument equation.nl() equation.summary.nls() causing warning R CMD check. Corrected now.

title: modelit 1.4.2
text: Bug correction autoplot.nls(): X Y axes inverted. Also deprecated aes_string() function replaced aes() proper arguments.

title: modelit 1.4.1
text: Slight adjustments space label units equations, allow beta instead beta_1 beta_0 beta_2 equations tables tabularise().

title: modelit 1.4.0
text: Use generic equation(). equation_nls() transformed equation() method nls summary.nls objects. Implementation ital_vars=, use_coefs=, coef_digits= fix_signs= arguments order get parameterized well non parameterized equation, without italic variables. Dependency {equatiomatic} dropped. now included {tabularise}. default title= argument now automatically set FALSE table generated inside chunk tbl-cap YAML entry defined (thus replaced caption). tabularise_default() methods summary.lm summary.glm lacking important information (identical tabularise_coef) objects. Corrected now.

title: modelit 1.3.0
text: tabularise_default() tabularise_tidy() added anova objects. tabularise_tidy() added aov objects.

title: modelit 1.2.0
text: tabularise_default(), tabularise_coef(), tabularise_glance(), tabularise_tidy() lm objects tabularise_default(), tabularise_coef() summary.lm objects tabularise_coef(), tabularise_glance(), tabularise_tidy() glm objects tabularise_coef() summary.glm objects

title: modelit 1.1.0
text: tabularise_default(), tabularise_coef(), tabularise_glance(), tabularise_tidy() nls objects tabularise_default(), tabularise_coef() summary.nls objects

title: modelit 1.0.0
text: autoplot() chart() objects lm, glm nls: plot model several residual analyses, plus composed 2x2 plot residuals analysis. .function() lm nls objects. Reexportation several functions {modelr}: add_predictions(), add_residuals(), geom_ref_line(), rmse(), rsquare(), mae() qae(). fit_model() easily fit {parsnip} model, series methods like summary(), anova() chart() directly implemented objects.

title: modelit 0.1.0
text: Added hex sticker (logo) : Added NEWS.md file track changes package.
code: SciViews::R p <- chart(data = mtcars, wt ~ mpg) + geom_point() p <- p + geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = y ~ I(x^2) + x) p <- p + theme_void() + hexSticker::theme_transparent() dir.create ("inst/figures", showWarnings = FALSE) hexSticker::sticker(p, package = "modelit", p_size = 9, s_x = 1, s_y = .75,   s_width = 1.3, s_height = 0.9, h_fill="lightblue3", h_color="blue",   filename = "inst/figures/modelit.png")
